Fix downloads badge

pypip.in has been down for a while, but http://shields.io/ is another service. 

This is the monthly badge; change `dm` to `dw` or `dd` for weekly or daily downloads.

[CI skip]
allow for multiple profile names in config file

Broke up --stream functionality

The --stream option has been separated out into --track --follow and
--locations to better match Twitter's filter stream API.

Similarly the `twarc.stream` function has been renamed to `twarc.filter`
and it now takes three parameters: track, follow and locations.

Example ranked list with most first

I find it useful to have the ranked list of most-tweeted URLs with the most-tweeted at the top instead of the bottom.
Fixed markup in updated geojson doc
cleaned reformatted, removed duplicated logic, fixed up command line arguments
Adds functions to listen to sample stream, collect from a user timeline, and to look up a user object.

ready for merge back into master
updated doc to indicate there is no longer a 5K limit
added trend functions to twarc, README, tests
moving to use command CLI patter

Replies

This commit includes functionality and a test for getting replies for a given
tweet. Twarc.replies operates on an iterator of tweet objects, since a user
screen name and the tweet_id are needed. The filename can be passed in
on the command line.

    twarc replies tweets.json > replies.json

Since Twitter's API doesn't support getting replies to a given tweet
twarc will use the search api to look for responses to a given user and then
filter those for tweets where the in_reply_to_status_id_str matches the
original tweet id. It also will recursively fetch replies to replies, unless
told not to.

replies for a tweet id

For convenience the command line can fetch replies to a given tweet id:

    twarc replies 323893983983 > replies.json

This commit also includes tests for replies that was previously not committed.

README: fix links to Wikipedia

A while age, a hyphen was added to the "Line-delimited JSON" section
of the "JSON streaming" Wikipedia page that the README links to.
(https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=JSON_streaming&type=revision&diff=prev&oldid=815227476)

This updates the links in all of the README files to use hyphens.

filter + lang

This commit adds the ability to filter tweets on language. You can use
from the command line, with one or more --lang arguments:

    twarc filter paris,madrid --lang es --lang fr

You can also use programatically:

    for tweet in t.filter('paris,madrid', lang=['es', 'sp']):
        print(tweet['full_text'])

Fixes #266
added @igorbrigadir's excellent guide to the search api

App Auth

The Twarc constructor now takes an optional app_auth parameter to tell
Twarc to use OAuth2 App Auth when connecting to the API. This has the
benefit of getting increased rate limits in some cases, but lower in
others, so check out the rate limits when using this:

https://developer.twitter.com/en/docs/basics/rate-limits

The default is User Auth (current behavior). It can also be set at the
command line:

    twarc --app_auth search covid_19 > tweets.jsonl

fixes #246
fixes #302

Premium API Support

This commit adds new functionality to search the Twitter Premium Search
API. From the command line you can now:

    twarc search blacklivesmatter --30day > tweets.jsonl

or:

    twarc search blacklivesmatter --fullarchive > tweets.jsonl

Depending on your query this could quickly use up your quota, so you
will likely want to use --from_date and --to_date to limit the time
range that you are searching. You can also use --limit to limit the
number of tweets that are retrieved.

If your app is only authorized for the sandbox you can use the --sandbox
parameter.

This functionality is made available through the new Twarc.premium_search
method.

Fixes #326

Retweets changes

This commit changes the behavior of the command line client so that it
can also fetch retweets from a file of tweet_ids.

    twarc retweets ids.txt > retweets.jsonl

This is in addition to the previous behavior where it accepted a tweet
id to fetch the retweets for:

    twarc retweets 20 > retweets.jsonl

You can also comma separate them:

    twarc retweets 20,21 > retweets.jsonl

The internal interface to the Twarc.reteets has changed to now accept an
iterator of tweet ids.

    from twarc import Twarc
    twitter = Twarc()

    for tweet in twitter.retweets([20, 21]):
        print(tweet['id_str'])
        ...

If you have been using the retweets method in your code you will want to
adjust it to pass in a list of ids rather than the bare ids.
